Yuck. Terrible components and extremely booring by today's standards. I'm not even talking about the crayons, which I am willing to overlook. It's impossible to read icons on the goods! And who in their right mind would flip through rulebook reading through a massive list of goods and locations and try to figure out where things go? This may have been "fun" in the Tactics II era (i.e. pre-color-TV), but... Gimme a break. The only people that might possibly buy this one are folks that have the locations and routes totally memorized (you know who you are), and have a hankering for some major nostalgia. No modern gamer would could possibly spend time playing this. Avoid - Railroad Tycoon would make a much better investment.

I'll lead with my bias: I'm not a huge fan of pick-up-and-deliver (PUAD). I find it tedious as a mechanic and most missteps result in back-tracking (the antithesis of fun). That said, I do kind of like route-building and I always appreciate a good train game.

Let's assume that the PUAD portion is at least average by other people's standards, even though to me it's tiresome. The problem with Empire Builder is the other component building blocks are all below average in their respective categories:

-The engine-buidling is really minimal relative to the scale of the game (the slope is not very steep and not very long)
-The economic component is flat and disinteresting without space for creative play
-The game is devoid of any real shared incentives with minimal player interaction (perhaps this is wanting it to be a stock game when it's not, maybe not a fair criticism)

I had many turns go by where I was just moving my piece the maximum distance and then passing. Not many fun things to think about or plan between turns to keep your mind engaged. You make a mental order of operations that is the most efficient combination of options available and you execute. *shrug*

I will say the route-building is pretty fun. And writing on the map is just money. There should be more crayons in games. I also appreciate that this game was a step in a new direction for train games, and honestly the rough outline of what would one day be Union Pacific/Ticket to Ride to me seems evident. I would much rather play TTR than EB. It's faster, the decision space is tighter and more interesting, the game arc has a steeper slope while also achieving a greater dynamic range, and it strips away pieces parts that are ok to let go.

Given that 1830 was more or less a contemporary, I can't give this one much leeway I'll often afford to older technology. I'm just not excited to play it again. But I guess I would if you love it and want me to.

There are some things I really enjoyed about it; you almost want to speculate on what goods someone will need as the values are by distance, so picking up trees/tourists/nickle and then heading west to try and get cards that work is an option that *almost* works. The simulation aspect of "how do rail lines evolve, when do you lease vs buy, etc" is really fascinating and almost overwhelming for novice players. Unfortunately, this falls flat and shows it's age; the event cards are straight 80s dickage, and the cards in general are difficult to get a solid handle on. Last, so many turns were spent just moving the 12 spaces and waiting. In that regard, it reminds me of High Frontier in so far as you make estimates based on factors that are sort of in your control, but you won't have a solid grasp on the commitment (of rail lines, and early goods/cash), and the second half (or two thirds) of the game is seeing if that commitment pays off. For that reason, I could see the short variant being a serious improvement, but it's just a product of it's age I guess...

It's one of those games that I probably wouldn't play now, but I remember fondly.

- Genuinely like how the game works. It's pretty easy to play, you create lines to do jobs, do jobs to create line. Getting connections to 5 major cities is the hard part, the rest is just spamming the contracts to victory.
- Being one of the earliest train games, i feel like it was alright for its time, but it needs some more modifications to fit the modern era, but it creates a brutal gameplay that's still pretty fun to play, and i really love the washable crayon provided by Mayfair.
- From the home rules printed in the box, i think this game has quite some followers. Obviously this is just a template for future train games, but if most modern train games are like this i'm quite intrigued.
My brain hurts too much after playing this.

I like the pickup and deliver style gameplay and the tough choices of what contracts to go for, and the skill in trying to figure out how to do everything efficiently. The rules are relatively simple, and everyone is participating over a shared board and space.

However, the parts I don't like include some lengthy downtime as others carefully plan out turns. It doesn't help that you often deliver and then pull some random events and contracts and then have to figure out right then what you're doing which means it's tough to plan ahead to make the turn go faster.

It's also just a tad on the fiddly end for me with players having to do lots of simple counting and changing of money in order to properly execute the game state. I don't think there's a clear way around it, and the game is interesting in the way it is, but overall there's just a tad too much time being spent on things other than interesting game decisions for this title to be great.

Empire Builder is the first of the crayon-rail games that set a new standard of "train" games and gives players that great "train" game feeling.

Empire Builder uses the tried and true crayon rail building system. Players use crayons to draw tracks on the board. Players then use their rails to make deliveries.

Empire Builder uses cards to power a simple pick-up and delivery system. Players pick-up good from one city then deliver those goods to another city to earn money. The first to set amount of money wins.

The crayon rail pick-up and delivery system is easy to learn. New players will quickly learn the game and start drawing their own rails.

Why not longer inventive, the crayon rail system was new for its time. It is fun to draw on the board. Sort of like a big kids coloring book.

The artwork is minimal at best, but the components are fine. Same goes for the theme. Empire Builder is more focused on mechanics then art and components.

Empire Builder is great teaching game. This is a wonderful way to learn the geography of the nation.
